description:
Torulaspora delbrueckii is a species of yeast that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a non-spore-forming, haploid, and unicellular fungus. T. delbrueckii is known for its ability to ferment a variety of sugars, including glucose, fructose, sucrose, and maltose, making it a valuable microorganism in the food and beverage industries.

This yeast species is characterized by its spherical or oval-shaped cells, which typically range in size from 3 to 6 micrometers in diameter. T. delbrueckii reproduces asexually through budding, where a new cell forms as a protrusion from the parent cell and eventually separates.

Torulaspora delbrueckii is commonly found in various natural environments, such as on the surfaces of fruits, flowers, and soil. It is also a well-known member of the microbial community in the fermentation of various alcoholic beverages, including wine, beer, and traditional fermented foods.

Due to its unique metabolic properties and potential applications in the food industry, T. delbrueckii has been the subject of extensive research, particularly in the areas of biotechnology and food science.
